correction_response:
This tweet is somewhat misleading. While it's true that House Republicans have proposed a 23% national sales tax, it's important to note that this tax is intended to replace the current tax system, not add to it. The proposal aims to abolish the IRS and simplify the tax code, not increase the financial burden on American families. However, there are concerns that such a tax system could disproportionately affect lower-income individuals and older adults. 
References: 
https://www.fox29.com/news/national-sales-tax-whats-behind-some-house-republicans-proposal
https://www.reuters.com/world/us/white-house-ask-house-republicans-come-clean-mccarthy-deals-2023-01-17/
note_1_text: While the bill does institute a 23% national sales tax, it also eliminates the income tax, payroll tax, and estate tax. It also includes a number of refunds and credits in chapter 2, and further refunds and rebates for families in chapter 3.    https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/25/text
note_2_text: The question isn’t “how would a sales tax replace an income tax”, but rather “what is the difference between taxing income versus consumption.” Sales taxes hit lower income people harder because a larger share of their income is used to consume. https://policybook.aarp.org/policy-book/taxation/income-tax-vs-consumption-tax
